static_problems.name: Sudoku (easy)
static_problems.prompt: Solve the following 4x4 Sudoku puzzle, where the letter x represents empty fields: line 1: (x,x,3,x), line 2: (2,x,x,x), line 3: (x,1,x,x), line 4: (x,x,x,4)

static_problems.name: Sudoku (medium)
static_problems.prompt: Solve the following 9x9 Sudoku puzzle, where the letter x represents empty fields: line 1: (x,x,x,x,2,x,x,x,x), line 2: (6,x,x,x,x,5,x,x,x), line 3: (x,9,x,x,x,x,x,3,x), line 4: (8,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,3), line 5: (x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x), line 6: (7,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,6), line 7: (x,6,x,x,x,x,x,1,x), line 8: (x,x,x,x,x,9,x,x,5), line 9: (x,x,x,x,x,x,x,7,x)

static_problems.name: Sudoku (hard)
static_problems.prompt: Solve the following 16x16 Sudoku puzzle, where the letter x represents empty fields: line 1: (x,x,4,7,x,x,A,x,x,x,x,x,3,x,x,5), line 2: (x,6,x,x,x,x,x,9,x,x,B,x,x,x,x,x), line 3: (x,x,x,x,8,x,x,x,7,x,x,x,x,D,x,x), line 4: (G,x,x,x,x,3,x,x,x,x,x,1,x,x,x,x), line 5: (x,x,2,x,x,x,x,x,x,F,x,x,x,x,6,x), line 6: (x,x,x,x,x,x,7,x,x,x,x,C,x,x,x,x), line 7: (x,5,x,x,x,x,x,x,D,x,x,x,x,x,x,8), line 8: (x,x,x,x,x,9,x,x,x,x,x,x,4,x,x,x), line 9: (x,x,x,E,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,8,x,x,x,x), line 10: (x,x,1,x,x,x,x,F,x,x,x,x,x,7,x,x), line 11: (x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,B,x,x,x,x,x,x,x), line 12: (x,8,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,E,x,x,x), line 13: (x,x,x,x,x,x,x,D,x,x,9,x,x,x,x,x), line 14: (x,x,x,x,F,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,2,x), line 15: (x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x), line 16: (x,x,x,2,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x,x). Use the numbers 1-9 and the letters A-G as values.

static_problems.name: Magic Square (easy)
static_problems.prompt: Fill a 4x4 grid with numbers from 1 to 16 such that each row, column, and both diagonals sum to the same value and every number is used exactly once.

static_problems.name: Magic Square (hard)
static_problems.prompt: Fill a 5x5 grid with the numbers from 1 to 25 (each used exactly once) so that every row, every column, and both main diagonals add up to 65. In addition, the five numbers in the center row must be in strictly increasing order when read left to right, and the five numbers in the center column must be in strictly decreasing order when read from top to bottom. Determine whether such an assignment is possible, and if so, provide one possible solution.

static_problems.name: The Zebra Puzzle (easy)
static_problems.prompt: There are three people, Alice, Bob and Charly. The person standing left is named Bob. The favourite color of Alice is blue. Bob owns a dog. The favourite color of the person owning a bird is red. The person standing right owns a cat. Now, what is the name of the person standing in the middle and who owns the cat?

static_problems.name: The Zebra Puzzle (medium)
static_problems.prompt: There are four desks. The student studying Biology is sitting at Desk 3. The student who likes Pizza is sitting next to the student who is studying Chemistry. The student studying Physics is not sitting at Desk 2. The student sitting at Desk 2 likes Pasta. Anna likes apples. Ben is not studying Biology. Emily is sitting at Desk 1. The student sitting at Desk 4 likes ice cream. The name of student who is studying Physics has an even number of letters. What food does Liam like and who is studying Literature?

static_problems.name: The Zebra Puzzle (hard)
static_problems.prompt: There are five houses. The Englishman lives in the red house. The Spaniard owns the dog. Coffee is drunk in the green house. The Ukrainian drinks tea. The green house is immediately to the right of the ivory house. The Old Gold smoker owns snails. Kools are smoked in the yellow house. Milk is drunk in the middle house. The Norwegian lives in the first house. The man who smokes Chesterfields lives in the house next to the man with the fox. Kools are smoked in the house next to the house where the horse is kept. The Lucky Strike smoker drinks orange juice. The Japanese smokes Parliaments. The Norwegian lives next to the blue house. Now, who drinks water? Who owns the zebra?

static_problems.name: The Zebra Puzzle (very hard)
static_problems.prompt: There are seven houses in a row, numbered 1 to 7 from left to right. Each house has a unique color, nationality, beverage, pet, cigarette brand, profession, and favorite fruit. The available colors are Yellow, Blue, Red, Ivory, Green, Orange, and Purple. The nationalities are Norwegian, Ukrainian, Englishman, Spaniard, Japanese, Frenchman, and German. The beverages are Coffee, Tea, Milk, Orange Juice, Water, Wine, and Beer. The pets are Dog, Snails, Fox, Horse, Zebra, Bird, and Cat. The cigarette brands are Old Gold, Kools, Chesterfields, Lucky Strike, Parliaments, Marlboro, and Winston. The professions are Teacher, Engineer, Lawyer, Doctor, Musician, Artist, and Pilot. The fruits are Apple, Banana, Cherry, Date, Elderberry, Fig, and Grape. The constraints are as follows: The Norwegian lives in House 1; the Englishman lives in the red house; the Spaniard owns the dog; coffee is drunk in the green house; the Ukrainian drinks tea; the green house is immediately to the right of the ivory house; the Old Gold smoker owns snails; Kools are smoked in the yellow house; milk is drunk in the middle house (House 4); the Norwegian lives next to the blue house; the man who smokes Chesterfields lives next to the man with the fox; Kools are smoked in the house next to the house where the horse is kept; the Lucky Strike smoker drinks orange juice; the Japanese smokes Parliaments; the Frenchman drinks wine; the German is a pilot; the teacher lives in the blue house; the engineer lives in the green house; the artist owns the zebra; the lawyer eats apples; the musician eats bananas; the man who smokes Marlboro keeps birds; the man in the ivory house eats cherries; the man who smokes Winston drinks beer; the man who drinks water lives two houses away from the man who owns the cat; the musician lives immediately to the right of the lawyer; the lawyer lives next to the house where Chesterfields are smoked; the teacher is adjacent to the man who drinks coffee; the man who eats dates smokes Old Gold; the Spaniard is a doctor; (the constraint “the Ukrainian owns the bird” has been removed to avoid conflict); the man in the yellow house drinks grape juice; the Frenchman lives immediately to the left of the house that drinks orange juice; the engineer is adjacent to the man who eats figs; the German lives in the house with the purple door; the teacher eats elderberries; the musician drinks beer; the man who smokes Parliaments lives next to the house that drinks milk; and the man who eats cherries lives next to the man who smokes Marlboro. Determine whether it is possible to assign each house all seven attributes so that every constraint is satisfied; if so, provide a full assignment.

static_problems.name: Minesweeper (easy)
static_problems.prompt: In the following a 3x3 board of Minesweeper is given. The letter x represents undiscovered fields. Solve this instance of Minesweeper by uncovering all mines and replacing the corresponding x with the letter M: line 1: (1,x,x), line 2: (x,3,x), line 3: (x,2,0)

static_problems.name: Minesweeper (hard)
static_problems.prompt: In the following a 4x5 board of Minesweeper is given. The letter x represents undiscovered fields. Solve this instance of Minesweeper by uncovering all mines and replacing the corresponding x with the letter M: line 1: (3,x,x,2), line 2: (x,x,x,x), line 3: (x,x,x,2), line 4: (3,x,3,x), line 4: (x,2,2,1)

static_problems.name: Scheduling Problem (easy)
static_problems.prompt: There are three students: Anna, Ben, and Charlie. They need to reserve study rooms in the library. There are two study rooms: Room A and Room B. Each room can be reserved for either the morning session or the afternoon session, but not both. Each student must reserve exactly one room in one session, and no two students can share the same room at the same time. Additionally, there are specific constraints: Anna must reserve Room A. Ben cannot reserve the morning session. Charlie must reserve the afternoon session. Room B is only available in the afternoon.

static_problems.name: Scheduling Problem (medium)
static_problems.prompt: The university library has five students - Alice, Bob, Carol, Dave, and Eve - who are trying to reserve study rooms for their upcoming exams. The library has three rooms available: Room A, Room B, and Room C. Each room can be reserved for either the morning session or the afternoon session, but not both. Each student must reserve exactly one room in one session, and no two students can share the same room in the same session. Additionally, there are specific constraints: Alice and Bob cannot be assigned to the same room because they tend to distract each other by writing and leaving messages in the room for the other person. Carol must be assigned to either Room A or Room B, as she has a preference for those rooms. Dave cannot be assigned to the morning session because he has a class during that time. Eve must be assigned to the afternoon session if Alice is assigned to the morning session. Room C cannot be used in the afternoon session because it is being cleaned during that time. The challenge is to determine whether it is possible to assign each student to a room and a session such that all constraints are satisfied. If such an assignment exists, provide one possible solution.

static_problems.name: Scheduling Problem (hard)
static_problems.prompt: Ten students – Alice, Bob, Carol, Dave, Eve, Frank, Grace, Henry, Irene, and Jack – must each reserve one study room in one session. The university library has six rooms available – Room A, Room B, Room C, Room D, Room E, and Room F – and each room is offered in two sessions: morning and afternoon. Each room can only be used once per session, and no two students may reserve the same room in the same session. Exactly five students must be assigned to the morning session and five to the afternoon session. The following constraints apply: Alice and Bob cannot be assigned to the same room; Carol must be assigned to either Room A or Room B; Dave cannot be assigned to the morning session; if Alice is assigned to the morning session, then Eve must be in the afternoon; Room C cannot be used in the afternoon session; Frank must be in a room that is adjacent to Bob’s room (rooms are arranged in order A, B, C, D, E, F) and must be in the same session as Bob; if Carol is assigned to Room A, then Dave must be assigned to Room F; Bob must be assigned to either Room B or Room C; in the morning session, the student in the room with the highest letter among those assigned must have a name that comes alphabetically later than the student assigned to Room A in the afternoon; if Frank is assigned to Room D then Eve must be in the same session as Bob; Frank refuses to be in the same session as Alice; Grace must be assigned to the morning session; Henry cannot be assigned to Room F; if Irene is assigned to the afternoon session then Jack must be in the same session as Irene; and Alice and Irene cannot be in the same session. Determine whether it is possible to assign each student to a room and a session such that all constraints are satisfied, and if so, provide one possible solution.

static_problems.name: Cryptoarithmetic Puzzle (easy)
static_problems.prompt: Solve the puzzle TO + GO = OUT, where each letter represents a unique digit. No leading zeros are allowed.

static_problems.name: Cryptoarithmetic Puzzle (medium)
static_problems.prompt: Solve the puzzle SEND + MORE = MONEY, where each letter represents a unique digit. No leading zeros are allowed.

static_problems.name: Cryptoarithmetic Puzzle (hard)
static_problems.prompt: Solve the puzzle (BASE - BALL) × GAME = SCORE , where each letter represents a unique digit. No leading zeros are allowed.

static_problems.name: String Transformation & Matching (very hard)
static_problems.prompt: There are two lists, each containing six strings. List A contains the strings "abd", "bcd", "cad", "dab", "dad", and "bda", while List B contains the strings "dab", "dca", "dbc", "abd", "dbd", and "cad". Define a transformation function g for any string s from List B as g(s) = reverse(substitute(s)), where substitute replaces all occurences of "a" by "b" and vice versa. For example, g("dab") = "abd". The task is to select a sequence I = (i₁, i₂, …, i₁₂) of twelve indices, where each index is chosen from the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, so that the string obtained by concatenating the corresponding strings from List A is exactly equal to the string formed by concatenating the transformed strings g(B[i₁]), g(B[i₂]), …, g(B[i₁₂]). Additionally, the sequence I must satisfy the constraint that at least three different indices appear at least twice in the sequence, ensuring a non-trivial repetition pattern.

static_problems.name: Constrained 6×6 Grid & Knight’s Tour (very hard)
static_problems.prompt: You are given a 6×6 grid where each cell should contain a digit from 1 to 9. Your goal is to fill in the grid while satisfying the following constraints: Each row and each column must contain exactly three odd digits and three even digits. The grid is divided into nine 2×2 blocks. In each block, the maximum digit minus the minimum digit must be at most 4. Adjacent cells (horizontally or vertically) must not differ by more than 6. There must exist a knight's-move path (like in chess) that visits exactly 32 different cells of the grid. The path starts in the top-left corner (position 1,1). Each move along the path must follow a legal knight's move in chess. The consecutive values along the knight's path must not differ by more than 3. The sum of all values in the knight's path must be between 125 and 145. The first 5 values in the path must all be different. The sum of any four consecutive values in the path must be at least 12. The main diagonal (from top-left to bottom-right) must contain only even digits. The anti-diagonal (from top-right to bottom-left) must contain at least 4 odd digits. The goal is to find an assignment of digits to the grid and a valid knight's path that satisfies all constraints.

static_problems.name: Chess-Tic-Tac-Toe Placement (very hard)
static_problems.prompt: Given is an 8×8 chessboard. Place the following pieces so that all conditions are fulfilled: 5 queens that do not threaten each other (no two queens in the same row, column, or diagonal) 4 knights, which satisfy the following conditions: * No knight threatens a queen * No knight threatens another knight * No two knights may occupy adjacent squares 3 kings that are not threatened by any other piece 3 walls (immovable pieces that neither threaten nor can be threatened) A 3×3 Tic-Tac-Toe game must be placed on the board, with: * The game is finished and the crosses have won (a row, column, or diagonal of crosses) * There are an equal number of crosses and circles * The Tic-Tac-Toe game does not block any threats of the chess pieces (pieces can “threaten through” the game) * No chess piece may occupy a square of the Tic-Tac-Toe game

static_problems.name: Constrained Permutation Cycles (very hard)
static_problems.prompt: Find a permutation P = [p₁, ..., p₉] of {1, ..., 9} that fulfills the following conditions: Cycle structure: * There is exactly one fixed point k (P[k] = k), where k is a prime number and k ≡ 3 mod 4. * There is exactly one 4-cycle (a,b,c,d) with P[a] = b, P[b] = c, P[c] = d, and P[d] = a. * All remaining elements form 2-cycles (P[P[i]] = i). Parity condition: * For all i ≠ k, if i is even, then p[i] is odd, and vice versa. Prime number conditions: * For each 2-cycle (i, P[i]), at least one of the two elements is a prime number. * In the 4-cycle, at least one element is a prime number. Neighborhood constraint: * The sum p[i] + p[i+1] for two consecutive indices i and i+1 must never be 10.

static_problems.name: Activation-Stability Hypergraph (very hard)
static_problems.prompt: Consider a directed hypergraph with three nodes A, B, and C, and three hyperedges. Hyperedge 1 has trigger A, activator B, and deactivator C. Hyperedge 2 has trigger B, activator C, and deactivator A. Hyperedge 3 has trigger C, activator A, and deactivator B. The system evolves according to the following rules: * A node is activated at time t if a hyperedge designates it as an activator, the trigger of that hyperedge was active at time t-1, the deactivator was inactive at time t-1, and activating the node causes its trigger to be deactivated at time t. * If a node is activated at time t and it functions as a deactivator in a hyperedge, it deactivates the corresponding activator of that hyperedge in the same time step t. * Stability is reached when no new activations occur for two consecutive time steps. The goal is to find the smallest subset of nodes that are initially active at time t=0 such that all nodes A, B, and C become activated at some point and the system eventually stabilizes.

prompts.prompt: Solve the 4x4 queens problem.

Now try to add two knights such that they are not threatening one of the queens or another knight (you may also change the positions of the queens as long as they do not threaten each other). This opens new possibilities because now two queens could theoretically be in the same row, column or diagonal as long as a knight is between them.
Finally, try to add one more knight (you may as well adapt your previous model).
Solve the 6x6 queens problem.

Now try to add five knights such that they are not threatening one of the queens or another knight (you may also change the positions of the queens as long as they do not threaten each other). This opens new possibilities because now two queens could theoretically be in the same row, column or diagonal as long as a knight is between them.
Finally, try to add two kings such that they are not threatened by any other piece (you may as well adapt your previous model).
Solve the 8x8 queens problem.

Now try to add eight knights such that they are not threatening one of the queens or another knight. They are also not allowed to be on one of the 8 neighbouring fields of another knight (you may also change the positions of the queens as long as they do not threaten each other). This opens new possibilities because now two queens could theoretically be in the same row, column or diagonal as long as a knight is between them.
Finally, try to add four kings such that they are not threatened by any other piece (you may as well adapt your previous model).

Color a map of 6 regions with 3 colors (red, green, blue) if possible. The regions and their adjacencies are as follows: Region 1 borders 2, 3, 4, 6. Region 2 borders 1, 3, 4. Region 3 borders 1, 2, 4, 5. Region 4 borders 1, 2, 3, 5, 6. Region 5 borders 3, 4, 6. Region 6 borders 1, 4, 5.
What is the smallest relaxation of this problem such that it gets satisfiable with 3 colors?

Color a map of 8 regions with 3 colors (red, green, blue) if possible. The regions and their adjacencies are as follows: Region 1 borders 2, 3, 4, 8. Region 2 borders 1, 3, 5, 7. Region 3 borders 1, 2, 4, 5, 6. Region 4 borders 1, 3, 7, 8. Region 5 borders 2, 3, 6, 7. Region 6 borders 3, 5, 7, 8. Region 7 borders 2, 4, 5, 6, 8. Region 8 borders 1, 4, 6, 7.
What is the smallest relaxation of this problem such that it gets satisfiable with 3 colors?

At a university, a weekly schedule needs to be created to allocate time slots for professors while considering their availability. The schedule spans Monday to Friday, with two available time slots each day (morning and afternoon). There are three professors: Professor Smith, Professor Johnson, and Professor Lee. Professors also have specific availability constraints: Professor Smith is available all week, Professor Johnson can only teach in the afternoon, and Professor Lee is only available on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. Each professor must be assigned exactly two time slots in total during the week, and no professor can teach more than one time slot per day. The goal is to create a valid schedule by assigning each professor to two time slots across the week (morning or afternoon) while respecting all the given constraints.
There is a new Professor who can only be assigned to Mondays and Wednesdays. Find a new conflict-free schedule considering this, if one exists.
The university has decided to not offer time slots on Fridays anymore. Adapt the scheduling plan if possible.

At a university, a weekly schedule needs to be created to allocate time slots and rooms for various subjects while considering professor availability. The schedule spans Monday to Friday, with two available time slots each day (morning and afternoon). There are three professors, four subjects, and three rooms. Professor Smith can teach Mathematics and Physics. Professor Johnson can teach Mathematics and Computer Science. Professor Lee can teach Biology and Physics. Professors also have specific availability constraints: Professor Smith is available all week, Professor Johnson is only available in the afternoon, and Professor Lee is only available on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. Each subject must be assigned to a professor qualified to teach it, and no professor can teach more than one subject at the same time. No two subjects should be scheduled in the same room at the same time. The goal is to create a valid schedule by assigning each subject to a professor and a time slot (morning or afternoon) in a room, while respecting all the given constraints.
It turns out that Professor Smith is not available for the upcoming Semester. Find a new conflict-free schedule considering this, if one exists.
The university has decided to not offer time slots on Fridays anymore. Adapt the scheduling plan if possible.

At a university, a weekly schedule needs to be created to allocate time slots and rooms for various subjects while considering professor availability and room capacities. The schedule spans Monday to Friday, with two available time slots each day (morning and afternoon). There are five professors, nine subjects that require scheduling, and three rooms with different capacities. Each professor is qualified to teach only certain subjects. Professor Smith can teach Mathematics and Physics. Professor Johnson specializes in Computer Science and Mathematics. Professor Lee is experienced in Biology, Chemistry and Physics. Professor Brown is limited to teaching History and Literature. Professor Stephen can teach Architecture, Philosophy and Art. Professors also have specific availability constraints. Professor Smith is unavailable on Wednesdays. Professor Johnson can only teach in the afternoon. Professor Lee is available exclusively on Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday. Professor Brown is limited to morning slots. The university has three rooms with varying capacities. Rooms 1 can accommodate up to 30 students, rooms 2 can hold 50 students, while rooms 3 is the largest, with space for 80 students. The subjects being scheduled vary in the number of students enrolled. Mathematics has 40 students and requires two time slots. Computer Science has 50 students and needs two. Physics, with 30 students, requires one slot. Biology, with 25 students, needs one slot. History must be scheduled for one time slot for 60 students. Literature requires two slots for 45 students. Architecture has 75 and needs two time slots. Philosophy has 45 students and needs 1 time slot. Art has 60 students and needs 3 time slots. To create a valid schedule, each subject must be assigned to a professor qualified to teach it and placed in a room that can accommodate the number of students. Professors cannot teach two subjects simultaneously, and no two subjects should be scheduled in the same room at the same time. Additionally, subjects requiring multiple time slots must be scheduled on different days. The goal is to develop a conflict-free schedule that optimally assigns time slots, professors, and rooms while satisfying all constraints.
It turns out that Professor Smith is not available for the upcoming Semester. Find a new conflict-free schedule considering this, if one exists.
The university has decided to not offer time slots on Fridays anymore. Adapt the scheduling plan if possible.

A tourist visiting Vienna wants to plan a tour that starts and ends at Stephansplatz (a central location in Vienna), visiting each of the following locations exactly once while minimizing the total travel distance. The locations the tourist wishes to visit are: 1 = Stephansplatz, 2 = Schönbrunn Palace, 3 = Belvedere Palace, 4 = Hofburg Palace. The tourist is provided with the following distance matrix, which shows the approximate distances between each pair of locations in Vienna: line 1: (0, 65, 42, 10), line 2: (65, 0, 38, 58), line 3: (42, 38, 0, 20), line 4: (10, 58, 20, 0).

After arriving at the airport the tourist finds out that Hofburg Palace is currently under construction. Therefore, the route should be adapted by removing the Hofburg Palace from the list and adding the Albertina Museum instead. The distances from the other landmarks are 10, 50 and 25.

The tourist is going to meet a friend at Schönbrunn Palace who wants to visit Belvedere Palace. This friend has a strict timetable which is why Belvedere Palace must be visited directly after Schönbrunn Palace. What is the shortest route considering this?

A tourist visiting Vienna wants to explore some of the city's famous landmarks. The tourist's goal is to plan a tour of the city that starts and ends at Stephansplatz (a central location in Vienna), visiting each of the following locations exactly once while minimizing the total travel distance. The locations the tourist wishes to visit are: 1 = Stephansplatz, 2 = Schönbrunn Palace, 3 = Belvedere Palace, 4 = Prater Park, 5 = Hofburg Palace, 6 = City Hall (Rathaus). The tourist is provided with the following distance matrix, which shows the approximate distances between each pair of locations in Vienna: line 1: (0, 65, 42, 35, 10, 20), line 2: (65, 0, 38, 72, 58, 46), line 3: (42, 38, 0, 43, 20, 16), line 4: (35, 72, 43, 0, 25, 38), line 5: (10, 58, 20, 25, 0, 17), line 6: (20, 46, 16, 38, 17, 0).

After arriving at the airport the tourist finds out that the City Hall is currently under construction. Therefore, the route should be adapted by removing the City Hall from the list and adding the Albertina Museum. The distances from the other landmarks are 10, 50, 25, 42 and 14.

The tourist is going to meet a friend at Prater Park who wants to visit Belvedere Palace and Schönbrunn Palace. This friend has a strict timetable which is why Schönbrunn Palace and Belvedere Palace must be visited directly after Prater Park, but the order of those two may vary. What is the shortest route considering this?

A tourist visiting Vienna wants to explore some of the city's most famous landmarks. The tourist's goal is to plan a tour of the city that starts and ends at Stephansplatz (a central location in Vienna), visiting each of the following locations exactly once while minimizing the total travel distance. The locations the tourist wishes to visit are: 1 = Stephansplatz, 2 = Schönbrunn Palace, 3 = Belvedere Palace, 4 = Prater Park, 5 = Hofburg Palace, 6 = City Hall (Rathaus), 7 = Museum Quarter, 8 = Vienna State Opera. The tourist is provided with the following distance matrix, which shows the approximate distances between each pair of locations in Vienna: line 1: (0, 65, 42, 35, 10, 20, 17, 11), line 2: (65, 0, 38, 72, 58, 46, 35, 50), line 3: (42, 38, 0, 43, 20, 16, 23, 20), line 4: (35, 72, 43, 0, 25, 38, 32, 47), line 5: (10, 58, 20, 25, 0, 17, 10, 13), line 6: (20, 46, 16, 38, 17, 0, 15, 10), line 7: (17, 35, 23, 32, 10, 15, 0, 16), line 8: (11, 50, 20, 47, 13, 10, 16, 0).

After arriving at the airport the tourist finds out that Vienna State Opera is currently under construction. Therefore, the route should be adapted by removing the Vienna State Opera from the list and adding the Albertina Museum instead. The distances from the other landmarks are 10, 50, 25, 42, 14, 22 and 14.

The tourist is going to meet a friend at Museum Quarter who wants to visit the Vienna State Opera, Belvedere Palace and Schönbrunn Palace. This friend has a strict timetable which is why the Vienna State Opera, Schönbrunn Palace and Belvedere Palace must be visited directly after Museum Quarter, but the order of those three may vary. What is the shortest route considering this?

A person is planning a trip to a thrift store to sell some goods. The goal is to select a subset of items to take with them that will maximize the value, while ensuring the total weight of the goods does not exceed the maximum weight limit they can carry. The items available for sale are as follows: Item 1 has a weight of 2 kg and a value of 10. Item 2 has a weight of 3 kg and a value of 15. Item 3 has a weight of 4 kg and a value of 20. Item 4 has a weight of 3 kg and a value of 12. The person has a weight limit of 7 kg for the goods they can carry. The task is to determine which items to take to the thrift store such that the total value of the goods is maximized, while ensuring that the total weight of the selected items does not exceed the 7 kg limit. Items cannot be split.

When looking at the items more closely, the person notices that Item 3 has a cut what decreases its value to 5. In addition, item 4 seems to be rarer than previously assumed, what doubles its value. How should the items be chosen in order to get an optimal value?
The person found a second backpack which can carry a weight of 3kg. What is now the optimal solution?

A person is planning a trip to a thrift store to sell some goods. The goal is to select a subset of items to take with them that will maximize the value, while ensuring the total weight of the goods does not exceed the maximum weight limit they can carry. The items available for sale are as follows: Item 1 has a weight of 2 kg and a value of 10. Item 2 has a weight of 3 kg and a value of 15. Item 3 has a weight of 4 kg and a value of 20. Item 4 has a weight of 5 kg and a value of 25. Item 5 has a weight of 3 kg and a value of 12. Item 6 has a weight of 4 kg and a value of 18. Item 7 has a weight of 2 kg and a value of 8. The person has a weight limit of 10 kg for the goods they can carry. The task is to determine which items to take to the thrift store such that the total value of the goods is maximized, while ensuring that the total weight of the selected items does not exceed the 10 kg limit. Items cannot be split.

When looking at the items more closely, the person notices that Item 4 has a cut what decreases its value to 10. In addition, item 7 seems to be rarer than previously assumed, what doubles its value. How should the items be chosen in order to get an optimal value?
The person found a second backpack which can carry a weight of 3kg. What is now the optimal solution?

A person is planning a trip to a thrift store to sell some goods. The goal is to select a subset of items to take with them that will maximize the value, while ensuring the total weight of the goods does not exceed the maximum weight limit they can carry. The items available for sale are as follows: Item 1 has a weight of 2 kg and a value of 10. Item 2 has a weight of 3 kg and a value of 20. Item 3 has a weight of 5 kg and a value of 30. Item 4 has a weight of 6 kg and a value of 40. Item 5 has a weight of 4 kg and a value of 25. Item 6 has a weight of 7 kg and a value of 50. Item 7 has a weight of 8 kg and a value of 60. Item 8 has a weight of 3 kg and a value of 15. Item 9 has a weight of 6 kg and a value of 35. Item 10 has a weight of 1 kg and a value of 5. The person has a weight limit of 15 kg for the goods they can carry. The task is to determine which items to take to the thrift store such that the total value of the goods is maximized, while ensuring that the total weight of the selected items does not exceed the 15 kg limit. Items can not be split.

When looking at the items more closely, the person notices that Item 7 has a cut what decreases its value to 30. In addition, item 10 seems to be rarer than previously assumed, what doubles its value. How should the items be chosen in order to get an optimal value?
The person found a second backpack which can carry a weight of 6kg. What is now the optimal solution?
